children.value: This document is a work in progress. Have you upgraded your site and run into something that’s not covered here?

hProperties.aria-label: introduction permalink

children.value: This is a reference for upgrading your site from Gatsby v1 to Gatsby v2. While there’s a lot covered here, you probably won’t need to do everything for your site. We’ll do our best to keep things easy to follow, and as sequential as possible so you can quickly get rocking on v2!
If you want to start fresh, check out the

hProperties.aria-label: why you should migrate permalink

children.value: of migrating from v1 to v2. The
is covered in various blog posts:

hProperties.aria-label: what well cover permalink

children.value: Convert to either pure CommonJS or pure ES6
APIs onPreRouteUpdate and onRouteUpdate no longer called with the route update action
Use Query in place of RootQueryType
Update CSS Modules class names that use dashes
Explicit query names no longer required
Only allow defined keys on the

hProperties.aria-label: updating your dependencies permalink

children.value: The very first thing you will need to do is update your dependencies and install any needed peer dependencies.

hProperties.aria-label: update gatsby version permalink

children.value: to use the latest version of Gatsby.

"dependencies": {
  "gatsby": "^2.0.0",
}
npm i gatsby@latest

hProperties.aria-label: update gatsby related packages permalink

children.value: to use the latest versions of Gatsby related packages. Any package name that starts with

should be upgraded. Note, this only applies to plugins managed in the gatsbyjs/gatsby repo. If you’re using community plugins, they might not be upgraded yet. Check their repo for the status. Many plugins won’t actually need upgrading so they very well might keep working. You can run
npm outdated
And compare “Wanted” and “Latest” versions and update
npm i gatsby-plugin-google-analytics@latest gatsby-plugin-netlify@latest gatsby-plugin-sass@latest
: Above command is just an example - adjust packages to ones you are actually using.

hProperties.aria-label: manually install react permalink

children.value: packages were included as part of the
so you are required to install them into your project.
npm i react react-dom

hProperties.aria-label: manually install plugins peer dependencies permalink

children.value: Some plugins had dependencies that were also made
npm i typography react-typography
Search for the plugins that you use in the
and check their installation instructions for additional packages that now need installed.

hProperties.aria-label: handling breaking changes permalink
remove or refactor layout components permalink

children.value: In Gatsby v2, the special layout component (
) that wrapped every page in Gatsby v1 has been removed. The “top level component” is now just the page itself. If the layout of your site looks broken, this is likely the reason why.
There are a number of implications to this change:
To render different layouts for different pages, just use the standard React inheritance model. Gatsby no longer maintains, or needs to maintain, separate behavior for handling layouts.

Because the “top level component” changes between each page, React will rerender all children. This means that shared components previously in a Gatsby v1 layout— like navigations— will unmount and remount. This will break CSS transitions or React state within those shared components. If your use case requires layout component to not unmount use
To learn more about the original decisions behind this removal, read the
RFC for removing the special layout component
The following migration path is recommended:

hProperties.aria-label: 1 convert the layouts children from a render prop to a normal prop required permalink

children.value: 1. Convert the layout’s children from a render prop to a normal prop (required)
prop passed to layout was a function (render prop) and needed to be executed. In v2, this is no longer the case.

import React from "react"

export default ({ children }) => (
  <div>
-    {children()}
+    {children}
  </div>
)

hProperties.aria-label: 2 move layoutsindexjs to srccomponentslayoutjs optional but recommended permalink

children.value: git mv src/layouts/index.js src/components/layout.js

hProperties.aria-label: 3 import and wrap pages with the layout component permalink

children.value: 3. Import and wrap pages with the layout component
Adhering to the normal React composition model, import your layout component and use it to wrap the content of the page.

import React from "react"
import Layout from "../components/layout"

export default () => (
  <Layout>
    <div>Hello World</div>
  </Layout>
)
Repeat for every page and template that needs this layout.

hProperties.aria-label: 4 pass history location and match props to layout permalink

children.value: In v1, the layout component had access to
props. In v2, only pages have access to these props; if you need these props in the layout component, pass them through from the page.

import React from "react"

export default ({ children, location }) => (
  <div>
    <p>Path is {location.pathname}</p>
    {children}
  </div>
)

import React from "react"
import Layout from "../components/layout"

export default props => (
  <Layout location={props.location}>
    <div>Hello World</div>
  </Layout>
)

hProperties.aria-label: 5 change query to use staticquery permalink

children.value: prop in your Gatsby v1 layout, you now need to make use of Gatsby v2’s
, since a layout is now a normal component.

import React, { Fragment } from "react"
import { Helmet } from "react-helmet"
+ import { StaticQuery, graphql } from "gatsby"

- export default ({ children, data }) => (
-   <>
-     <Helmet titleTemplate={`%s | ${data.site.siteMetadata.title}`} defaultTitle={data.site.siteMetadata.title} />
-     <div>
-       {children()}
-     </div>
-   </>
- )
-
- export const query = graphql`
-   query LayoutQuery {
-     site {
-       siteMetadata {
-         title
-       }
-     }
-   }
- `
+ export default ({ children }) => (
+   <StaticQuery
+     query={graphql`
+       query LayoutQuery {
+         site {
+           siteMetadata {
+             title
+           }
+         }
+       }
+     `}
+     render={data => (
+       <>
+         <Helmet titleTemplate={`%s | ${data.site.siteMetadata.title}`} defaultTitle={data.site.siteMetadata.title} />
+         <div>
+           {children}
+         </div>
+       </>
+     )}
+   />
+ )

hProperties.aria-label: change navigateto to navigate permalink

children.value: In addition to the name change,
is now directly exported from the
package and can’t be installed directly.

import React from "react"
- import { navigateTo } from "gatsby-link"
+ import { navigate } from "gatsby"

// Don't use navigate with an onClick btw :-)
// Generally just use the `<Link>` component.
export default props => (
-  <div onClick={() => navigateTo(`/`)}>Click to go to home</div>
+  <div onClick={() => navigate(`/`)}>Click to go to home</div>
)

hProperties.aria-label: convert to either pure commonjs or pure es6 permalink

children.value: Convert to either pure CommonJS or pure ES6
Gatsby v2 uses webpack 4 which is stricter about modules with mixed module systems.

// GOOD: ES modules syntax works
import foo from "foo"
export default foo

// GOOD: CommonJS syntax works
const foo = require("foo")
module.exports = foo

// BAD: Mixed ES and CommonJS module syntax will cause failures
const foo = require("foo")
export default foo

// BAD: Mixed ES and CommonJS module syntax will cause failures
import foo from "foo"
module.exports = foo

hProperties.aria-label: move babel configuration permalink

children.value: The latest version of Gatsby uses Babel 7, which introduced
a new behavior for configuration lookup / resolution
file might have been used at the root of the project, like for configuring Jest, moving that Babel configuration into
documents the steps needed to do that.
More information on Gatsby and Babel configuration available

hProperties.aria-label: restore v1 postcss plugin setup permalink

children.value: To have the same configuration that you had in v1 (if you were using these plugins), you should use
and follow the recommended migration path below.

hProperties.aria-label: 1 install the dependencies permalink

children.value: npm install --save gatsby-plugin-postcss postcss-import postcss-cssnext postcss-browser-reporter postcss-reporter
and it is better to use

hProperties.aria-label: 2 include gatsby plugin postcss in your gatsby configjs file permalink

children.value: plugins: [`gatsby-plugin-postcss`],

hProperties.aria-label: 3 include postcss plugins in your postcssconfigjs file permalink

children.value:
const postcssImport = require(`postcss-import`)
const postcssCssNext = require(`postcss-cssnext`)
const postcssBrowserReporter = require(`postcss-browser-reporter`)
const postcssReporter = require(`postcss-reporter`)

module.exports = () => ({
  plugins: [
    postcssImport(),
    postcssCssNext(),
    postcssBrowserReporter(),
    postcssReporter(),
  ],
})

hProperties.aria-label: migrate from react router to reachrouter permalink

children.value:
as @reach/router is smaller and most importantly, has 1st class support
for accessibility.

, who was also the founder of React Router. He says @reach/router restores
things he misses from React Router v3 while retaining the best parts of React Router v4
sites, this change won’t cause any breaking changes as the two routers are quite similar.
You use the object form of the
Read more about the features of our new router at

One prominent feature of @reach/router, relative routes, isn’t working currently in Gatsby. We’re working with Ryan Florence
on fixing that so hopefully it’ll be supported soon.
Read on for instructions on migrating your site to @reach/router.

hProperties.aria-label: only string to allowed permalink

children.value: React Router allowed you to pass objects to the

<Link
  to={{ pathname: `/about/`, search: `fun=true&pizza=false`, hash: `people` }}
>
  Our people
</Link>
React Router would then simply concatenate the object values together into the full pathname e.g.
Now you’ll need to concatenate together the full pathname yourself.

- <Link to={{ pathname: `/about/`, search: `fun=true&pizza=false`, hash: `people`}}>Our people</Link>
+ <Link to={`/about/?fun=true&pizza=false#people`}>Our people</Link>

hProperties.aria-label: pass state to the state prop permalink

children.value: Previously with React Router to pass state to a link, you would pass it as part of a
Now, to add state to a link, pass it via a

const NewsFeed = () => (
  <div>
    <Link to="photos/123" state={{ fromFeed: true }} />
  </div>
)

const Photo = ({ location, photoId }) => {
  if (location.state.fromFeed) {
    return <FromFeedPhoto id={photoId} />
  } else {
    return <Photo id={photoId} />
  }
}

hProperties.aria-label: a history prop is no longer passed to page components permalink

children.value: prop is no longer passed to page components
prop to components that you could use to navigate.
If you need to do programmatic navigation, import instead the @reach/router’s
import { navigate } from "@reach/router"

hProperties.aria-label: the following props are no longer available on link permalink

children.value: The following props are no longer available on

are no longer necessary as @reach/router does matching
this way by default.

previously to manually compute whether the
link is active or not. For advanced link stylings, use

hProperties.aria-label: use getprops for advanced link styling permalink

children.value: If you have more advanced styling needs,

hProperties.aria-label: change client paths to use a splat permalink

children.value: Change client paths to use a splat
When creating a client route in
to select all child routes instead of

exports.onCreatePage = async ({ page, actions }) => {
  const { createPage } = actions

  // page.matchPath is a special key that's used for matching pages
  // only on the client.
  if (page.path.match(/^\/app/)) {
-    page.matchPath = "/app/:path"
+    page.matchPath = "/app/*"

    // Update the page.
    createPage(page)
  }
}

hProperties.aria-label: migrating react router client routes to reachrouter permalink

children.value: Migrating React Router client routes to @reach/router
for programmatic navigation instead of the history object
component any more. You add a
component (a site can have as many routers as it wishes) and then the immediate children of

import React from "react"
import { Router } from "@reach/router"

export default () => (
  <Router>
    <div path="/">I am the home!</div>
    <div path="/about">Here's a bit about me</div>
    <div path="/store">Buy my t-shirts!</div>
  </Router>
)
Here’s a more complex example of migrating a

component (used
in store.gatsbyjs.org) from React Router to @reach/router.

import React from 'react';
-import { Redirect, Route } from 'react-router-dom';
+import { Router, navigate } from '@reach/router';
 import { isAuthenticated } from '../../utils/auth';

-export default ({ component: Component, ...rest }) => (
-  <Route
-    {...rest}
-    render={props =>
-      !isAuthenticated() ? (
-        // If we’re not logged in, redirect to the home page.
-        <Redirect to={{ pathname: '/login' }} />
-      ) : (
-        <Component {...props} />
-      )
-    }
-  />
-);
+export default ({ component: Component, ...rest }) => {
+  if (!isAuthenticated() && window.location.pathname !== `/login`) {
+    // If we’re not logged in, redirect to the home page.
+    navigate(`/app/login`);
+    return null;
+  }
+
+  return (
+    <Router>
+      <Component {...rest} />
+    </Router>
+  );
+};
Here’s links to diffs for three sites with client routes that were upgraded to @reach/router

hProperties.aria-label: apis onprerouteupdate and onrouteupdate no longer called with the route update action permalink

children.value: no longer called with the route update action

React Router v4 would tell us the “action” (push/replace) that triggered the route
transition. We passed this as one of the arguments along with
to plugins. @reach/router doesn’t support this so we’ve removed it from the API calls.

hProperties.aria-label: browser api replaceroutercomponent was removed permalink

children.value: React Router allowed you to swap out its history object. To enable this in Gatsby, an API,
was added so that you could use a custom version of history or React Router. As @reach/router doesn’t support this, we’ve removed this API.
We did, erroneously, suggest using this API for adding support for Redux, etc. where you need to wrap the root Gatsby component with your own component.
for this, you’ll need to migrate to

import React from 'react'
import { Provider } from 'react-redux'
-import { Router } from 'react-router-dom'

-export const replaceRouterComponent = ({ history }) => {
+export const wrapRootElement = ({ element }) => {
-  const ConnectedRouterWrapper = ({ children }) => (
+  const ConnectedRootElement = (
    <Provider store={store}>
-      <Router history={history}>{children}</Router>
+      {element}
    </Provider>
  )

-  return ConnectedRouterWrapper
+  return ConnectedRootElement
}

hProperties.aria-label: browser api replacehistory was removed permalink

children.value:
, we no longer support custom histories so this was removed.
The
method could be used for tracking page views as it is possible to register listeners on route changes using
In order to track page views, you can use the

hProperties.aria-label: browser api wraprootcomponent was replaced with wraprootelement permalink

children.value: will return Element and not Component. This change was needed to keep all wrapping APIs uniform.

-export const wrapRootComponent = ({ Root }) => {
+export const wrapRootElement = ({ element }) => {
-  const ConnectedRootComponent = () => (
+  const ConnectedRootElement = (
    <Provider store={store}>
-      <Root />
+      {element}
    </Provider>
  )
-  return ConnectedRootComponent
+  return ConnectedRootElement
}

hProperties.aria-label: dont query nodes by id permalink

children.value: Source and transformer plugins now use UUIDs for IDs. If you used glob or regex to query nodes by id then you’ll need to query something else.
Here’s an example querying an image:

query MyImageQuery {
    allImageSharp(filter: {
-     id: {regex: "/default.jpg/"}
+     fluid: {originalName: {regex: "/default.jpg/"}}
    }) {
      edges {
        node {
          id
          fluid(maxWidth: 660) {
            src
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
See the Pull Request that implemented this change

hProperties.aria-label: use query in place of rootquerytype permalink

children.value: The GraphQL root type has been changed from
. This is only likely to impact you if you have top-level fragments in your GraphQL queries:

query Blog {
    ...Sidebar
    blogPosts {
      title
      slug
    }
  }

- fragment Sidebar on RootQueryType {
+ fragment Sidebar on Query {
    siteDescription
  }
}

hProperties.aria-label: typographyjs plugin config changes permalink

children.value: , you now need to explicitly export
as named exports from your typography config module.

- const typography = new Typography();
- export default typography;

+ const typography = new Typography();
+ const { rhythm, scale } = typography;
+ export { rhythm, scale, typography as default };

hProperties.aria-label: update css modules class names that use dashes permalink

children.value: Update CSS Modules class names that use dashes
If you use CSS Modules and have class names with dashes in them, you’ll need to change how you access the class names from JavaScript.
for CSS Modules has been changed from
Here’s an example with a class named

import React from "react"
import myStyles from "./my.module.css"

export default ({ children }) => (
-  <div className={myStyles['my-class-name']}>
+  <div className={myStyles.myClassName}>
    {children}
  </div>
)
The Gatsby v1 behavior can be restored by adjusting
For vanilla CSS without a preprocessor:

const cssLoaderRe = /\/css-loader\//
const targetFile = `.module.css`

const processRule = rule => {
  if (rule.oneOf) {
    return {
      ...rule,
      oneOf: rule.oneOf.map(processRule),
    }
  }

  if (!rule.test.test(targetFile)) {
    return rule
  }

  if (Array.isArray(rule.use)) {
    return {
      ...rule,
      use: rule.use.map(use => {
        if (!cssLoaderRe.test(use.loader)) {
          return use
        }

        // adjust css-loader options
        return {
          ...use,
          options: {
            ...use.options,
            camelCase: false,
          },
        }
      }),
    }
  }

  return rule
}

exports.onCreateWebpackConfig = ({ getConfig, actions }) => {
  const config = getConfig()

  const newConfig = {
    ...config,
    module: {
      ...config.module,
      rules: config.module.rules.map(processRule),
    },
  }
  actions.replaceWebpackConfig(newConfig)
}
If you’re using a preprocessor, you can pass in CSS Loader options when configuring

// in gatsby-config.js
plugins: [
  {
    resolve: `gatsby-plugin-sass`,
    options: {
      cssLoaderOptions: {
        camelCase: false,
      },
    },
  },
]

<Img

Similarly, if you have created any CSS styling rules referencing the
class, you should merge those styles into the

import link from gatsby permalink

children.value: All components and utility functions from
package. Therefore you should import it directly from

import React from "react"
- import Link from "gatsby-link"
+ import { Link } from "gatsby"

export default props => (
  <Link to="/">Home</Link>
)
Furthermore you can remove the package from the

"dependencies": {
  "gatsby": "latest",
  "gatsby-image": "latest",
  "gatsby-plugin-sharp": "latest",

hProperties.aria-label: import graphql from gatsby permalink

children.value: tag function that Gatsby v1 auto-supports is deprecated in v2. Gatsby will throw deprecation warning unless you explicitly import it from the

import React from "react"
+ import { graphql } from "gatsby"

export default ({ data }) => (
  <h1>{data.site.siteMetadata.title}</h1>
)

export const query = graphql`
  query HomeQuery {
    site {
      siteMetadata {
        title
      }
    }
  }
`
There is a codemod that can automatically make this change to your projects. Check out the
Note that if you are relying on the auto-import feature of WebStorm or VSCode, it may import
. This will throw a bunch of errors around bad imports. Make sure

hProperties.aria-label: rename boundactioncreators to actions permalink

children.value: is deprecated in v2. You can continue using it, but it’s recommended that you rename it to

hProperties.aria-label: rename pathcontext to pagecontext permalink
rename responsive image queries permalink

children.value: queries are deprecated in v2. These queries have been renamed to
to make them easier to understand. You can continue using the deprecated query names, but it’s recommended that you update them.
Update image query and fragment names:

import React from "react"
import { graphql } from "gatsby"

const Example = ({ data }) => {
  <div>
-    <Img sizes={data.foo.childImageSharp.sizes} />
-    <Img resolutions={data.bar.childImageSharp.resolutions} />
+    <Img fluid={data.foo.childImageSharp.fluid} />
+    <Img fixed={data.bar.childImageSharp.fixed} />
  </div>
}

export default Example

export const pageQuery = graphql`
  query IndexQuery {
    foo: file(relativePath: { regex: "/foo.jpg/" }) {
      childImageSharp {
-        sizes(maxWidth: 700) {
-          ...GatsbyImageSharpSizes_tracedSVG
+        fluid(maxWidth: 700) {
+          ...GatsbyImageSharpFluid_tracedSVG
        }
      }
    }
    bar: file(relativePath: { regex: "/bar.jpg/" }) {
      childImageSharp {
-        resolutions(width: 500) {
-          ...GatsbyImageSharpResolutions_withWebp
+        fixed(width: 500) {
+          ...GatsbyImageSharpFixed_withWebp
        }
      }
    }
  }
`
Further examples can be found in the

hProperties.aria-label: delete nodes api deprecated permalink

children.value: is now deprecated, so instead you should write

hProperties.aria-label: other changes worth noting permalink
explicit query names no longer required permalink

children.value: Explicit query names no longer required
Gatsby v2 doesn’t require explicit query names. You can skip them now:

export const query = graphql`
-  query ThisIsExplicitQueryName($slug: String!) {
+  query($slug: String!) {
    markdownRemark(fields: { slug: { eq: $slug } }) {
      html
      frontmatter {
        title
      }
    }
  }
keyword if you don’t use query variables:

export const query = graphql`
-  query ThisIsAnotherExplicitQueryName {
+  {
    site {
      siteMetadata {
        title
      }
    }
  }
This isn’t a breaking change. Queries with explicit names will continue to work as they did in v1.

hProperties.aria-label: remove inlined css in htmljs permalink

children.value: Gatsby v2 will automatically inline your CSS. You can remove any custom CSS inlining from your custom
and unless it was used for anything else specifically, you can also remove

hProperties.aria-label: remove explicit polyfills permalink

children.value: If your Gatsby v1 site included any polyfills, you can remove them. Gatsby v2 ships with babel 7 and is configured to automatically include polyfills for your code. See
Gatsby’s babel docs for more details
Note: This works for your own code, but is not yet implemented for code imported from
. Track progress of this feature at

hProperties.aria-label: for plugin maintainers permalink

children.value: In most cases you won’t have to do anything to be v2 compatible, however there are a few things you can do to be certain your plugin will work well with v2 sites.

hProperties.aria-label: setting the proper peer dependencies permalink

children.value: of your plugin and it should specify the proper versions of support.

"peerDependencies": {
-  "gatsby": "1"
+  "gatsby": ">=1"
}

hProperties.aria-label: change modifywebpackconfig to oncreatewebpackconfig permalink

children.value: to bring it in line with the rest of Gatsby’s API names.

- exports.modifyWebpackConfig = ({ config, stage }) => {
+ exports.onCreateWebpackConfig = ({ stage, actions }) => {
  switch (stage) {
    case `build-javascript`:
-       config.plugin(`Foo`, webpackFooPlugin, null)
-       break
-   }
-   return config
+       actions.setWebpackConfig({
+         plugins: [webpackFooPlugin],
+       })
+   }
}
Gatsby’s webpack docs for more details

hProperties.aria-label: createremotefilenode permalink

children.value: The signature for using createRemoteFileNode changed in v2, it now expects a new parameter

hProperties.aria-label: only allow defined keys on the node internal object permalink

children.value: Only allow defined keys on the node internal object

The node internal object isn’t meant for adding node data. Those should be added to the top-level object. We
didn’t document this in v1 nor validate against it but are now for v2.

children.value: Schema must contain unique named types but contains multiple types named "<typename>"
exports all builtin GraphQL types as well as

-const { GraphQLString } = require(`graphql`)
+const { GraphQLString } = require(`gatsby/graphql`)

hProperties.aria-label: for explorers permalink
starting a new project with v2 permalink

children.value: Starting a New Project with v2
Here’s a brief section on starting a new project with Gatsby v2 instead of upgrading an existing project.
kind of person, you can install Gatsby and React like this:
If you’d like a step-by-step guide,
to get started with Gatsby v2.
If you’d rather use one of the official starters, install your favourite one with the Gatsby CLI.
